chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Balanitis - children
chapter.summary: Covers the management of suspected or confirmed balanitis in boys up to 16 years of age in primary care.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 1 month to 16 years (Male).

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: Management
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
If a child has suspected balanitis:

  • Advise the child or parents/carers to clean the penis daily with lukewarm water and to dry it gently.
    • Do not attempt to retract the foreskin to clean under it, if it is still fixed.
    • Do not use soap, bubble bath, or baby wipes as these may irritate the area.
    • Nappies should be changed frequently — see the CKS topic on Nappy rash for more information.
  • Advise on sources of written information and support, such as:
    • The NHS information leaflet on Balanitis.
    • The Patient.info information leaflet on Balanitis.
  • For suspected non-specific dermatitis:
    • Prescribe topical hydrocortisone 1% cream or ointment once a day and an imidazole cream, the frequency depending on the preparation used, until symptoms settle or for up to 14 days.
      • See the CKS topic on Corticosteroids - topical (skin), nose, and eyes for more information.
      • See the section on Topical imidazoles in the section on Prescribing information for more information.
  • For suspected irritant or allergic contact dermatitis:
    • Advise the person to stop any suspected triggers (such as soap, bubble bath, or creams).
    • Prescribe topical hydrocortisone 1% cream or ointment once a day until symptoms settle, or for up to 14 days.
      • See the CKS topic on Corticosteroids - topical (skin), nose, and eyes for more information.
    • Advise on the use of a regular emollient and for use as a soap substitute. See the CKS topic on Dermatitis - contact for more information.
  • For suspected or confirmed candidal balanitis:
    • Prescribe an imidazole cream, the frequency depending on the preparation used, until symptoms settle or for up to 14 days.
      • See the section on Topical imidazoles in the section on Prescribing information for more information.
    • If inflammation is causing discomfort, consider prescribing topical hydrocortisone 1% cream or ointment for up to 14 days in addition.
      • See the CKS topic on Corticosteroids - topical (skin), nose, and eyes for more information.
  • For suspected or confirmed bacterial balanitis:
    • Prescribe oral flucloxacillin for seven days. If the person is allergic to penicillin, prescribe oral clarithromycin for seven days.
      • See the sections on Flucloxacillin and Clarithromycin in the section on Prescribing information for more information including dosage regimens.
    • If inflammation is causing discomfort, consider prescribing topical hydrocortisone 1% cream or ointment for up to 14 days in addition.
      • See the CKS topic on Corticosteroids - topical (skin), nose, and eyes for more information.
  • For suspected seborrhoeic dermatitis, see the CKS topic on Seborrhoeic dermatitis for more information on management.
  • If symptoms are not improving following seven days of initial treatment:
    • Stop treatment with topical hydrocortisone (if using).
    • Take a sub-preputial swab to exclude or confirm a fungal or bacterial infection, and treat accordingly. Be aware that:
      • Group B streptococcus is usually a commensal and does not usually need treatment.
      • Candida may be a superadded infection and its presence does not exclude an underlying skin condition.
  • Arrange a blood test for HbA1c to assess for underlying diabetes mellitus if balanitis is severe, persistent, or recurrent (especially if candidal balanitis is present). See the CKS topics on Diabetes - type 1 and Diabetes - type 2 for more information.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on management are largely based on the British Association of Paediatric Urologists (BAPU) publication Management of foreskin conditions [British Association of Paediatric Urologists, 2013], and have been extrapolated from expert opinion in guidelines for people aged 16 years and older in the 2013 European guideline for the management of balanoposthitis [Edwards, 2014] and in the Royal College of General Practitioners and British Association of Sexual Health and HIV (RCGP/BASHH) publication Sexually transmitted infections in primary care [Lazaro, 2013].

  • CKS found no evidence for the comparative effectiveness of different topical imidazole preparations for the management of balanitis.
  • The recommendation on the use of flucloxacillin for suspected or confirmed bacterial balanitis is pragmatic based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice, as this antibiotic has activity against group A beta-haemolytic streptococci and Staphylococcus aureus. It is also based on the expert opinion of previous external reviewers of this CKS topic.
  • The recommendations on the significance of culture of group B streptococcus and candida following sub-preputial swabbing are extrapolated from expert opinion in the RCGP/BASHH publication [Lazaro, 2013] and the European guideline [Edwards, 2014].

subChapters.htmlHeader: When should I refer a child?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Arrange referral to a paediatrician, paediatric dermatologist, or paediatric urologist or surgeon, depending on the most likely underlying cause and clinical judgement, if:
    • The diagnosis is uncertain.
    • There is persistent or recurrent balanitis which is not responding to management in primary care — circumcision may be considered.
    • There is suspected lichen sclerosus and/or persistent phimosis — refer to a paediatric urologist or surgeon for consideration of circumcision.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on referral are largely based on expert opinion in the British Association of Paediatric Urologists (BAPU) publication Management of foreskin conditions [British Association of Paediatric Urologists, 2013], and are extrapolated from expert opinion in the 2013 European guideline for the management of balanoposthitis [Edwards, 2014]. They are also based on expert opinion in a review article on benign paediatric penile skin conditions [Castagnetti, 2015].

  • Persistent balanitis which does not respond to optimal treatment in primary care and with no evidence of an underlying infective cause after sub-preputial swabs may benefit from surgical assessment, as circumcision in these cases can be curative [Edwards, 2014].
  • The BAPU publication states that the medical indications for circumcision include balanitis xerotica obliterans and severe, recurrent attacks of balanitis [British Association of Paediatric Urologists, 2013].
